'''Love''' has several different meanings in [[English language|English]], from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something one would die for ([[patriotism]], pairbonding). It can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. Probably due to its psychological relevance, love is one of the most common themes in art.
 
'''Love''' has several different meanings in [[English language|English]], from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something one would die for ([[patriotism]], pairbonding). It can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. Probably due to its psychological relevance, love is one of the most common themes in art.
  +   +
Love might best defined as acting intentionally, in response to others (including God), to promote overall well-being (Oord). In this, love has a degree of freedom and this freedom is expressed in relation to others in the effort to promote the common good.
     
Just as there are many types of lovers, there are many kinds of love. Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
